Award.AwardTitle: Nuclear Physics with Electromagnetic Probes at Jefferson Lab
Award.AbstractNarration: This research is part of a large effort in the Hall A experimental research area at Jefferson Laboratory. Our scientific interest is to help constrain the so-called "equation of state" of nuclear matter, a critical ingredient to understanding the makeup of dense stars. We do this by scattering a beam of polarized electrons from the nuclei of lead atoms, where the dependence of the scattering probability on polarization direction tells us the average distribution of neutrons in this large, spherical nucleus. The contribution funded here is for a precision apparatus that would tell us the degree of polarization of the electron beam. Such an apparatus is also critical for a large number of different experiments in Hall A, and is consequently a service to the nuclear physics community. The scientific impact on the nuclear physics and nuclear astrophysics communities is very large, and the work is carried out with a number of students in various disciplines, at different levels. Consequently, students gain training not only in nuclear physics, but in magnetic transport applications and precision engineering, both as undergraduates and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The most important outcomes are related to the elucidation of the three dimensional structure of the nucleon, expressed in terms of the generalized parton distributions (GPDs). During the past few years, the RPI group has played leading roles in experiments which are directly related to these distributions. These are the following:

 

1. Deeply virtual Compton scattering: . This experiment is sensitive to the leading “twist 2” quark helicity conserving GPDs, and in particular the GPD, H.

For the first time  we obtained a very large kinematic range of precision differential cross sections and beam polarized cross section differences . These were compared with various theoretical calculations. The results for one measurement of s and Ds as function a of  f, for one bin out of the 126 measured distribution of Q2, xB and t, are shown in  Figure 1 below. Also, the result of a calculation using the model of Vanderhaeghen , Guichon and Guidal (VGG )(1) are shown as solid lines. One sees a rather good agreement with the obtained data.

Fig. 1 uploaded

Figure 1 caption.  Left: The cross section  s vs fp for one out of  126 kinematic bins in Q2 and xB. Right: Cross section difference  for longitudinal polarized electrons for the corresponding kinematics. The solid green curves are the results of the GPD based calculation of VGG.

2. Deeply virtual pseudoscalar meson electroproduction: e+p →e′+p′+π0 and e+p →e′+p′+η. These experiments have been shown to be dominated by the non-leading “twist 3” transversity GPDs, and in particular, ET.  As in the DVCS experiments, we have measured 4-fold  differential cross sections  in almost 100 bins of Q2, xB and t and obtained deconvolutions of the structure functions σU, σLT and σTT.  The resulting structure functions vs t for one of the bins in Q2 and  xB  is shown in Figure. 2. The curves correspond to the theoretical distributions of the structure functions and generalized form factors (GFF) calculated by Goloskokov and Kroll (GK)(2) using a twist-3 GPD formalism.

Fig. 2 uploaded

Figure 2 caption . Upper left: Structure functions σU (black), σLT (red) and σTT (blue) for π0 electroproduction as a function of  -t for one bin in Q2 and xB. Upper right: the extracted generalized form factors . Lower left and right: Same as for the upper graphs but for h electroproduction. The solid curves are due to the  the  calculations of GK.

Using the model of GK one obtains the GPDs ET and HT  for π0 and η production vs. xB and t for this particular Q2. This is shown for π0 in Fig. 3.  As a reminder, ET maps out the longitudinal and transverse distribution of the active quarks whose spins are flipped in this reaction. This is interpreted as the distribution of quarks in the nucleon pointing perpendicular to the direction of the nucleon spin.

Figure 3 uploaded.

Figure 3 caption. The GPDs ET and HT for π0 production vs. xB and t obtained with the model of GK.

 

The resulting  GFFs for  for π0 and η production can be combined to obtain the GFFs for the individual quark flavors in the nucleon.  This has been done for the CLAS data (3) and the preliminary results are shown in Fig. 4. From one can obtain ETu and ETd, which are once again directly related to the distribution of up and down quarks in the nucleon pointing perpendicular to the direction of the nucleon spin.

Figure 4 uploaded.

Figure 4 caption. The CLAS preliminary results ‹ET›u and ‹ET›d , and ‹HT›u and ‹HT›d obtained by combining the π0 and η GFFs
